DOC.HEAD: Arnold Moss, Classical Actor, Dead at 80
DOC.TEXT: Arnold Moss, an acclaimed classical actor who also headed a Shakespearean company, portrayed movie villains and played the voice of God in an opera, has died at age 80. He died Friday of lung cancer in his Manhattan home. Moss was praised by critics for his performances as Prospero in ``The Tempest'' in 1945 and as Malvolio in ``Twelfth Night'' in 1949. He formed his own repertory company, the Shakespeare Festival Players and toured 50 American colleges. In movies, he often played the heavy and appeared in ``Viva Zapata,'' ``Salome,'' ``Kim,'' ``Gambit,'' ``Casanova's Big Night'' and ``My Favorite Spy.'' Moss narrated with the Boston, Detroit and Milwaukee orchestras and provided the voice of God for the 1978 Chicago Lyric Opera Company production of ``Paradise Lost,'' doubling as poet John Milton. He began his stage career as actor-director at Eva LeGallienne's Civic Repertory Theatre in New York. The ruthless Spanish colonel in Ernest Hemingway's ``The Fifth Column'' was his first major Broadway role, and Moss went on to win approval for his parts in ``The Front Page,'' ``Flight to the West,'' and ``Journey to Jerusalem.'' Moss performed on radio, too, in soap operas, as a spokesman for the New York Philharmonic Orchestra and as a staff announcer for CBS Radio in New York. The State Department sent him to Latin America, Africa and the Far East as a specialist in theater. Surivors include his wife, Stella; his daughter, Andrea, of Croton-on-Hudson; and his son, Jeffrey, of Manhattan.
